//Code2 campaignTrail_temp.cyoa = true; function getQuestionNumberFromPk(pk) { return campaignTrail_temp.questions_json.map(q=>q.pk).indexOf(pk)-1; } cyoAdventure = function (a) { ans = campaignTrail_temp.player_answers[campaignTrail_temp.player_answers.length-1]; } function ctsAchievement(achievement, difficultyChecker = true){ if ((difficultyChecker && campaignTrail_temp.difficulty_level_multiplier<=1)||!difficultyChecker) if(campaignTrail_temp.CTS){ unlockAchievement(achievement); } } campaignTrail_temp.questions_json = [ { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 13500, "fields": { "priority": 1, "description": "You watch from the Oval Office as the combined might of the American Right descends on Washington DC with the single aim of ending the government you and your ticket fought so hard to establish. Secret Service agents shuttle in and out of the room, preparing an escape strategy, whilst your superior sits in the President's chair, oddly calm. “There's no need to panic,” Coxey smiles up at you warmly, “These good men are just angry because of the rough deal the previous administration gave them. I'm sure if we sit down with them and address their worries, they'll pack up and head home.”

Your brother sprints into the office, his face white with fear, and pulls you to the side. “Bob… They're at the gates. We need to do something, anything.”", "likelihood": 1 } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 13501, "fields": { "priority": 2, "description": "You stand below the Capitol building, before a crowd of thousands, eagerly awaiting the country's first steps into a new era. You can feel Butler's eyes burning into the back of your skull as you repeat Justice Hughes’ words back to him, sealing your fate as America’s shepherd through these rough times. There’s a sudden wave of anxiety through your body, but it dissipates the instant you see Dorothy’s warm smile.

The event fades into the background as you discuss everything from narodism to military strategy, finding much common ground despite your differing ideologies. The day ends with you both sat in a nearby movie theatre, sharing a drink over some low-budget Western." } } ] campaignTrail_temp.jet_data = [{ "mapping_enabled": false, "mapping_data": {}, "cyoa_enabled": true, "cyoa_data": {}, "nicknames": { "116": "Fascist", "117": "Republican", "118": "Democrat", "119": "Progressive" } } ] //Jet's Tool edits the code from this point upwards //Tooltips function getTooltips(str) { let matches = []; tooltipList.forEach((tooltip, index) => { // Adjust the regex to match searchString potentially surrounded by “ and followed by optional punctuation let regex = new RegExp(`(?<=\\b|\\s|^|“)${tooltip.searchString}(?=[.,;!?]?\\b|\\s|”|$)`, 'g'); let match; while ((match = regex.exec(str)) !== null) { matches.push({ start: match.index + (match[0].startsWith('“') ? 1 : 0), // Adjust for potential starting “ end: match.index + match[0].length - (match[0].endsWith('”') ? 1 : 0) - (match[2] ? 1 : 0), tooltipIndex: index }); } }); // Sort by starting position; if two start at the same position, longer match comes first matches.sort((a, b) => a.start - b.start || b.end - b.start - (a.end - a.start)); // Filter out overlaps for (let i = 0; i < matches.length - 1;) { if (matches[i + 1].start < matches[i].end) { matches.splice(i + 1, 1); // Remove the next match since it overlaps } else { i++; // Move to next match } } return matches; } function applyTooltips(str) { const matches = getTooltips(str); let result = ''; let lastIndex = 0; matches.forEach(match => { const tooltip = tooltipList[match.tooltipIndex]; result += str.slice(lastIndex, match.start); result += `${tooltip.searchString}${tooltip.explanationText}`; lastIndex = match.end; }); result += str.slice(lastIndex); // Add the remainder of the original string return result; } function applyTooltipsToObject(obj) { for (let key in obj) { if (typeof obj[key] === 'string') { obj[key] = applyTooltips(obj[key]); } else if (typeof obj[key] === 'object') { applyTooltipsToObject(obj[key]); // Recursive call } } } applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.questions_json); applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.answers_json); applyTooltipsToObject(campaignTrail_temp.answer_feedback_json); //Formatting campaignTrail_temp.candidate_image_url = "https://i.postimg.cc/Y9w8X8rY/MOW-Coxey-Candidate.png"; campaignTrail_temp.running_mate_image_url = "https://i.postimg.cc/9f9Jtshc/MOW-La-Follette-Candidate.png"; campaignTrail_temp.candidate_last_name = "Coxey Sr."; campaignTrail_temp.running_mate_last_name = "La Follette Jr."; campaignTrail_temp.election_json[0]["fields"].advisor_url = "https://i.postimg.cc/KcfQNnd3/Coxey-Advisor-Feedback.png"; corrr = '\n

IWWAgitation += 2; } } function adjustFeedbackBox(width, height) { // The width and heights are percentages. let styles = ` .overlay_window { height: ${height / 1.2}%; width: ${width}%; top: ${(100 - height) / 2}%; left: ${(100 - width) / 2}%; } ` var styleSheet = document.createElement("style") styleSheet.textContent = styles document.head.appendChild(styleSheet) } adjustFeedbackBox(57, 69); e = campaignTrail_temp function addHeadquarterButton() { // Check if the button already exists if (document.getElementById('headquarter_button')) { return; } // Find the reference button by its ID const refButton = document.getElementById('view_electoral_map'); if (!refButton) { return; } // Create a new button element const newButton = document.createElement('button'); newButton.id = 'headquarter_button'; newButton.style.marginLeft = '1.5em'; newButton.innerHTML = 'State of the Nation'; // Attach the click event listener newButton.addEventListener('click', openHeadquarter); // Insert the new button next to the reference button refButton.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', newButton); } function openHeadquarter() { /* Leaving this in here: instead of having the functions in the text, if you want, you can have the text change based on the number from the function, like so. You'll need to create a secondary function to hold the text, and then call that function in the text. - Astro */ //Legislative Goodwill if (LegislativeGoodwill < 1) { CongressScore = 'hostile' } if (LegislativeGoodwill > 0) { CongressScore = 'willing to work with you' } //NEC Approval if (NECApproval > 12) { NECHappy = 'a positive' } if (NECApproval < 13 && NECApproval > 7) { NECHappy = 'a nuanced' } if (NECApproval < 8 && NECApproval > 3) { NECHappy = 'a poor' } if (NECApproval < 4) { NECHappy = 'an abysmal' } //Mussolini Meter if (MussoliniMeter < 6) { Fashy = 'nonexistent' } if (MussoliniMeter > 5 && MussoliniMeter < 10) { Fashy = 'few and far between' } if (MussoliniMeter > 9 && MussoliniMeter < 15) { Fashy = 'noteworthy' } if (MussoliniMeter > 14 && MussoliniMeter < 21) { Fashy = 'striking' } if (MussoliniMeter > 20) { Fashy = 'blindingly obvious' } //Isolationism if (Isolationism > 9) { IsolationLevel = 'isolationist' } if (Isolationism < 10 && Isolationism > 7) { IsolationLevel = 'defensive' } if (Isolationism < 8 && Isolationism > 5) { IsolationLevel = 'cautious' } if (Isolationism < 6 && Isolationism > 3) { IsolationLevel = 'pragmatic' } if (Isolationism < 4 && Isolationism > 0) { IsolationLevel = 'interventionist' } if (Isolationism < 1) { IsolationLevel = 'aggressive' } //IWWAgitation if (IWWAgitation < 1) { WobbleLevel = 'docile' } if (IWWAgitation > 0 && IWWAgitation < 5) { WobbleLevel = 'frustrated' } if (IWWAgitation > 4 && IWWAgitation < 9) { WobbleLevel = 'agitated' } if (IWWAgitation > 8 && IWWAgitation < 13) { WobbleLevel = 'furious' } if (IWWAgitation > 12 && IWWAgitation < 17) { WobbleLevel = 'irate' } if (IWWAgitation > 16) { WobbleLevel = 'in open revolt' } let questions = document.querySelector(".inner_window_question"); questions.style.display = 'none'; const hqButton = document.getElementById('headquarter_button'); if (hqButton) { hqButton.remove(); } // Create and set up the headquarters div let hqDiv = document.createElement('div'); hqDiv.id = 'headquarter'; hqDiv.style.display = 'flex'; // Set layout to flex to allow columns hqDiv.style.color = 'white'; hqDiv.style.backgroundColor = '#383838'; hqDiv.style.backgroundImage = 'url(https://i.postimg.cc/wB8hGnm6/MOW-Variable-Headquarters-Background.png)'; // Set background image. I would recommend using the same file size as the original image, ~959 x 327. Otherwise it will stretch the image. Comment or remove this line of text if you don't want a background image and instead want hqDiv.style.backgroundColor to set your background color hqDiv.style.border = '5px solid black'; hqDiv.style.borderRadius = '10px'; hqDiv.style.height = '42%'; hqDiv.style.flexDirection = 'column'; hqDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; // Create header div let headerDiv = document.createElement('div'); headerDiv.style.display = 'flex'; headerDiv.style.justifyContent = 'space-between'; headerDiv.style.width = '100%'; headerDiv.style.alignItems = 'center'; // Add back button to the header let backButton = document.createElement('button'); backButton.innerText = 'Back'; backButton.style.margin = '5px' backButton.style.backgroundColor = 'grey'; backButton.onclick = function () { // Hide headquarters and show the original content hqDiv.remove(); questions.style.display = ''; } headerDiv.appendChild(backButton); /* This is a header text that you can add if you want to. It is not necessary. - Astro let headerText = document.createElement('h3'); headerText.textContent = 'Chief of Staff - Campaign Info'; headerText.style.textAlign = 'center'; // Center the text headerText.style.flexGrow = '1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available headerDiv.appendChild(headerText); */ // Append headerDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(headerDiv); // Create a container div for both columns let columnsDiv = document.createElement('div'); columnsDiv.style.display = 'flex'; columnsDiv.style.width = '100%'; // Create inner divs for columns let leftCol = document.createElement('div'); leftCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(leftCol); let rightCol = document.createElement('div'); rightCol.style.width = '50%'; columnsDiv.appendChild(rightCol); // Append columnsDiv to the main hqDiv hqDiv.appendChild(columnsDiv); questions.parentNode.insertBefore(hqDiv, questions.nextSibling); // This is the bulk of the content you can edit. You can add more text or images here. // Create Bulk of the Text // Duplicate this section to add more lines of text. Make sure to change the variable name "a" to something else. In this case, I changed it to "b". let Congress = document.createElement('p'); Congress.textContent = 'Congress is ' + CongressScore + '. (' + LegislativeGoodwill + ')'; // This is the text that will be displayed. You can change this to whatever you want. ' + function + ' will display the number from the function. // a.style.flexGrow = '0.1'; // Make h3 take up the maximum space available Congress.style.color = 'black'; // Can be used to change the color of the text Congress.style.fontSize = '20px'; Congress.style.fontWeight = 'bold'; Congress.style.margin = '8px'; // Can be used to change the space in between the text. Useful if you have a lot of functions. hqDiv.appendChild(Congress); let NECRelations = document.createElement('p'); NECRelations.textContent = 'The National Emergency Committee has ' + NECHappy + ' opinion of your leadership. (' + NECApproval + ')'; NECRelations.style.color = 'black'; NECRelations.style.fontSize = '20px'; NECRelations.style.fontWeight = 'bold'; NECRelations.style.margin = '8px'; hqDiv.appendChild(NECRelations); let ChildCult = document.createElement('p'); ChildCult.textContent = 'The populace think the similarities between you and Mussolini are ' + Fashy + '. (' + MussoliniMeter + ')'; ChildCult.style.color = 'black'; ChildCult.style.fontSize = '20px'; ChildCult.style.fontWeight = 'bold'; ChildCult.style.margin = '8px'; hqDiv.appendChild(ChildCult); let ForeignPolicy = document.createElement('p'); ForeignPolicy.textContent = 'Your foreign policy is viewed as ' + IsolationLevel + '. (' + Isolationism + ')'; ForeignPolicy.style.color = 'black'; ForeignPolicy.style.fontSize = '20px'; ForeignPolicy.style.fontWeight = 'bold'; ForeignPolicy.style.margin = '8px'; hqDiv.appendChild(ForeignPolicy); let AngryWobblies = document.createElement('p'); AngryWobblies.textContent = 'The Industrial Workers of the World, and the left as a whole, are currently ' + WobbleLevel + '. (' + IWWAgitation + ')'; AngryWobblies.style.color = 'black'; AngryWobblies.style.fontSize = '20px'; AngryWobblies.style.fontWeight = 'bold'; AngryWobblies.style.margin = '8px'; hqDiv.appendChild(AngryWobblies); } function handleMutations(mutationsList, observer) { if (observerRunning) return; observerRunning = true; addHeadquarterButton() observer.observe(document.documentElement, {childList: true, subtree: true}); observerRunning = false; } let observerRunning = false; var element = document.getElementById('controlElement'); if (!element) { let singleObserver = new MutationObserver(handleMutations); singleObserver.observe(document.documentElement, {childList: true, subtree: true}); var controlElement = document.createElement('div'); controlElement.style.display = 'none'; controlElement.id = 'controlElement'; document.body.appendChild(controlElement); } vpTable = { "Richard Washburn Child": "Grayson M. P. Murphy", "Eugene Talmadge": "Irénée du Pont", "James E. Van Zandt": "Julius Meier", "Huey Long": "Eugene Talmadge", "Herbert Hoover": "Robert Taft", "Joseph Irwin France": "William Borah", "John Nance Garner": "Henry Skillman Breckinridge", "Cordell Hull": "Joseph C. O'Mahoney", "Jacob S. Coxey Sr.": "Robert M. La Follette Jr.", "Robert M. La Follette Jr.": "Hjalmar Petersen", "Henry Wallace": "Norman Thomas", } vpTableHistorical = { "Richard Washburn Child": "Grayson M. P. Murphy", "Joseph Irwin France": "William Borah", "John Nance Garner": "Henry Skillman Breckinridge", "Robert M. La Follette Jr.": "Hjalmar Petersen", } function onGameWindowChangeCandidates() { const resultsTableHolder = document.getElementById("overall_details_container"); if (!resultsTableHolder || resultsTableHolder.classList.contains("done")) { return; } resultsTableHolder.classList.add("done"); const resultsTable = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[3].childNodes[3].children[0]; for (let i = 0; i < resultsTable.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTable.children[i]; let name = row.firstChild.innerText; row.insertCell(1); if (name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); console.log("name is:" + name) } if (i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTable[name]; } } const resultsTableHistorical = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[5].childNodes[3].children[0]; for (let i = 0; i < resultsTableHistorical.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTableHistorical.children[i]; let name = row.childNodes[1].innerText; row.insertCell(1); if (name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); } if (i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTableHistorical[name]; } } } const gameWindowNode = document.getElementById("game_window"); const candidateWatcherConfig = {attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true}; const candidateObserver = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChangeCandidates); candidateObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, candidateWatcherConfig); // Endings // constructs endings based on header and pages construct = (a = 1) => { e.page = e.page + a < e.pages.length ? e.page + a : 0 let html = e.header; html += e.pages[e.page] + "
"; if (e.page > 0) { html += `` } if (e.page < e.pages.length - 1) { html += `` } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; width: 70%; text-overflow: ellipsis; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; ` } }, 10) else if (e.image) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0]; if (candImg) candImg.src = e.image; }, 10) return html; } endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); } // ENDINGS -- this is slightly more reliable than the ending code method e.multiple_endings = true; endingPicker = (out, totv, aa, quickstats) => { //out = "win", "loss", or "tie" for your candidate //totv = total votes in entire election //aa = all final overall results data //quickstat = relevant data on candidate performance (format: your candidate's electoral vote count, your candidate's popular vote share, your candidate's raw vote total) /* e.header = "

" e.pages = ["

", "

"] */ document.head.innerHTML += ` `; //Special Achievements if (e.final_overall_results.find((f) => f.candidate === 119).electoral_votes > 0 && PFLATicket === 1) { ctsAchievement("If Debs could do it…"); } if (aa[0].candidate === 116 && quickstats[0] > 265 && ButlerCult > 2 && IWWAgitation < 17 && TalmadgePrimary < 3 && VanZandtPrimary < 3 && LongLives < 3) { ctsAchievement("What Letters?"); } if (aa[0].candidate === 116 && quickstats[0] > 265 && IWWAgitation < 1 && IWWAgitation < 17 && TalmadgePrimary < 3 && VanZandtPrimary < 3 && LongLives < 3) { ctsAchievement("World’s Most Agreeable Fascist"); } if (aa[0].candidate === 116 && quickstats[0] > 265 && Isolationism < 1 && IWWAgitation < 17 && TalmadgePrimary < 3 && VanZandtPrimary < 3 && LongLives < 3) { ctsAchievement("The Nationalist International"); } if (aa[0].candidate === 116 && quickstats[0] > 265) { //Victory Endings if (MussoliniMeter < 15 && NECApproval > 7 && IWWAgitation < 17 && TalmadgePrimary < 3 && VanZandtPrimary < 3 && LongLives < 3) { e.header = "

Four More Years

" e.pages = ["

You stand below the Capitol building, before a crowd of thousands, in a scene nearly identical to the one three and a half years ago. But now, you’re not playing second fiddle to some unwilling general, borrowing the attention of a congregation assembled for him - you’re the President, and this congregation was yours.

Dorothy stands by your side, her hand in yours as she walks you up to the podium for your speech. “Look at them, Richard,” she whispered, nodding out at the sea of flags and banners, “they’re all here for you.”

Your lips purse involuntarily, grumbling in acknowledgement. This crowd wasn’t any bigger than the one at your first speech. If anything, it was a bit smaller. You had spent months leading this ungrateful mob of a population, and they couldn’t even be bothered to turn up for your inauguration? Were you always destined to remain in the shadow of your predecessor?

Your focus meanders to the stands, scanning the rows of foreign dignitaries. An uncharacteristically laid-back looking Edward Wood sits next to Kuno von Westarp, mutually conversing as if their nations didn’t have decades of unresolved tension. A couple seats over, Aarón Sáenz Garza rests his chin in his hand, observing your supporters with mild revulsion. Eventually, your gaze rests on the centre of the front row, where you had specifically requested there be a reserved seat, only to see it occupied by Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister. Your heart sinks.

“He didn't come…” The words feebly escape your lips.

Dorothy frowns sympathetically, squeezing your hand. “It's alright, honey,” she consoled, “maybe he's just busy. You know how hard governing is…” She leans in, pressing an encouraging kiss to your cheek, “now, forget about all that and show these people just why they elected you.”

Smiling weakly at your wife, you straighten your posture and step up to the podium to the sound of raucous cheers. Out of the corner of your eye, you see the members of the NEC lined up at the side of the stage, most too caught up in their own conversations to spare you a second thought. You can’t help but wonder if they’re already discussing who they’ll get to replace you in four years time.

No. Dorothy was right, you need to forget about all that. At least just for now. Even if they discard you in ‘40, even if they continue to order you around like a dog, for the next four years all eyes are on you, and that knowledge fills you with a sense of pride that writing detective novels never could.

You clear your throat, turning your attention out to the National Mall.

Redundacy

" e.pages = ["

You stride through the halls of the White House, the jubilant celebrations of the reinauguration crowd still audible through the walls. Dorothy walks with you all the way towards the Oval Office, her arm looped through yours as she regales you with earnest compliments.

“My husband, President for another four years,” she chuckles lightly, gazing up at you with a pride that warms your frigid soul, “aren’t I just the luckiest woman in the world? I’m proud of you, Richard. I really am.”

You push open the door to your coveted workspace, only to find the fifteen other members of the Committee already present, occupying the various couches and chairs. Behind your desk sits a straight-faced Murphy, his hands clasped together over a small collection of documents. Something wasn’t right.

“I’ll leave you men to talk business, then?” Dorothy anxiously simpers towards the Committee, shooting you a concerned look before departing. You’re suddenly overcome with an intense awareness that you’ve just been cornered.

Murphy nods at you from his seat, not getting up. “Congratulations, Richard. Well done on a race hard-won,” a twinge of sorrow underlies his honeyed words, “if you could just take a seat-”

You ignore his request, stepping further into the den of snakes. “What’s happened? What’s gone wrong?”

“You have, Mister Child,” Ford rises from the couch, pointing a wrinkled digit at you, “you and these last three years. We’ve been trying to work with you, but you’ve been too self-righteous and egotistical to take our advice.”

Blindsided by the sudden aggression, your voice begins to tremble. “I- I admit that I may have disappointed you on some occasions-”

Hearst is the next to take to his feet, cutting you off with a coarse guffaw. “Hah! Disappointed?” he snipes, “that’s a fucking understatement. You may as well be Coxey himself with how well you’ve governed. If it weren’t for us you would’ve emptied the treasury by now. Probably would’ve tried to empty our bank accounts, too.”

The rest of the room burbles in agreement. “William is exaggerating, as usual,” your Vice President waves at the standing men, prompting them to return to their seats, “but he’s not wrong. This arrangement does not work anymore.”

You look towards Bush and Johnson, your ideological brethren, but their resigned expressions chip away at your will to resist. You’re just too much of a liability for this administration.”

No response forms in your mind. You stand below the Capitol building, before a crowd of thousands, in a scene nearly identical to the one three and a half years ago. But now, you’re not playing second fiddle to some unwilling general, borrowing the attention of a congregation assembled for him - you’re the President, and this congregation was yours.

Dorothy stands by your side, her hand in yours as she walks you up to the podium for your speech. “Look at them, Richard,” she whispered, nodding out at the sea of flags and banners, “they’re all here for you.”

Swarms of uniformed Legionnaires and gleeful citizens, many of which had travelled across the country just to attend, were practically clambering over one another to get a good look at you. It was the sort of scene you had only ever observed during your time in Italy, or the recurring dreams since.

An uncharacteristically laid-back looking Edward Wood sits next to Kuno von Westarp, mutually conversing as if their nations didn’t have decades of unresolved tension. A couple seats over, Aarón Sáenz Garza rests his chin in his hand, observing your supporters with mild revulsion. He meets your eyes and flashes you a toothy grin. You fire one back.

Dorothy stops before the podium, granting you a soft, supporting peck on the lips. “Good luck, darling,” she coos, letting go of your hand, “you’re going to do great.”

Rectification

" e.pages = ["

You stride through the halls of the White House, the jubilant celebrations of the reinauguration crowd still audible through the walls. Dorothy walks with you all the way towards the Oval Office, her arm looped through yours as she regales you with earnest compliments.

“My husband, President for another four years,” she chuckles lightly, gazing up at you with a pride that warms your frigid soul, “aren’t I just the luckiest woman in the world? I’m proud of you, Richard. I really-.”

She falls silent as she sees the intimidating figure of George Van Horn Moseley posted up outside the door to the office, pistol holstered by his side. The fascist grants the two of you a curt salute, before gesturing towards the enclosed room. “They’re already in there, Mister President.”

So Bush was right - they were really going to try this as soon as they could. “Thank you, George,” you shift towards Dorothy, planting a contrite kiss on her cheek, “I’m going to need a couple minutes, darling. I’ll meet you back at our room, okay?”

You watch her scurry off before marching inside, head held high. As expected, the rest of the Committee are already seated inside, their whispered argument dying down as soon as they notice your entrance. “And what do I owe this pleasure to, gentlemen?” You settle down in your rightful seat, peculiarly left vacant by the rebellious committee members. Half of the room share hesitant expressions with one another, “Oh, come on, there must be some reason you’re all here. Masters of politicking like you prefer to schedule your meetings in advance.”

Finally, someone stands: Henry Ford. “We’re here because of your actions, Richard,” the industrialist clarifies, eyes sweeping his comrades in search for support, “Your time in office has, frankly, been subpar and in conflict with the interests of this committee.”

You raise your eyebrows in mock surprise. “It has? Well, that’s a real shame, especially since I don’t intend to change anything.”

“That doesn’t matter,” Hearst joins Ford on his feet, “You’re no longer needed here. You are to resign as president before the year ends, to be replaced by someone less egotistical. If you don’t, the Committee will be forced to-”

“Forced to what?” You flatly cut him off, surprising everyone in the present with your sudden authority - including yourself, “Honestly, I'm surprised you're still in business with such a poor understanding of public opinion. But, then again, your papers are little more than mindless slop.”

The publisher laughs in disbelief. “I beg your pardon?!”

“Out of all the individuals in this room, who has the largest and most devoted following? Do any of the rest of you have a nationwide paramilitary utterly loyal to your vision?” the chants from the crowd outside, still yet to disperse, thrum faintly beneath your words, “Can you boast a public perception that isn't just ‘stingy oligarch’? I'm afraid that this little coup of yours is a couple months too late.”

Heast shoots an anxious look towards a dumbfounded Ford. In a fit of desperation, Davis pipes up. “You're bluffing. We have the media, we have the connections, you-”

“The only thing you're going to have is a quick trial. GEORGE!”

A small squad of legionnaires burst into the office via both doors, their weapons drawn and pointed at the traitors. Moseley’s eyes flash with sadistic delight as he follows in behind them, roughly cuffing Ford, Hearst and Davis, whilst the seated committee members watch on with a mix of dread and relief.

“You two-faced papist bastard!” Spittle flies from Henry’s mouth as he yells at you, “you fucking jewish crony! I hope they string you up by your feet-!” A painful crack rings out as a young legionnaire slams the butt of his rifle into the industrialist’s nose, sending blood pouring down his philtrum. You stifle a laugh.

“Thank you, friends. Take them away.” With a flick of your hand, the armed men abide, parading the three potential putschists out of the room and leaving behind a stunned Committee. “Now, are there any more grievances I should know of?” Your former puppet masters regard you with an obedient terror, none daring to speak. “Good. I'll see you all at dinner tonight. I have a number of suggestions about these next four years. On the Shoulders of Failures

" e.pages = ["

“That should be everything for today. It’s good to have you on board, Mister President.”

The rest of the Committee murmurs in agreement at Murphy’s statement, offering Eugene a series of polite smiles and firm handshakes before shuffling out of the Oval Office. You remain perched on the couch, watching the southerner as he runs his hand across the desk you once sat behind. President Talmadge? What a joke. That fool couldn’t govern his state for a month without pissing off the entire political class - handing him the keys to power was equivalent to putting the country in a basket and sending it over a waterfall.

“Do you need something Richard?” The unworthy successor drawled, his voice an insult to your ears. You stand up, forcing a grin, though it comes out as a constipated grimace.

“No, Eugene, I don’t. I was just wondering how your first day in office has been. It’s a stressful job.”

The President kicks his feet up on the table, a cocky laugh escaping his maw. You feel your jaw tighten at the sight of his shoes dirtying your former workspace. “Maybe it was for you, but I’m doing just fine. Nothing this job throws at me could be harder than the bullshit I wrangled my way out of in Atlanta.”

A switch flips somewhere in the southerner’s brain and he leaps to his feet, his effortless charm vanishing in favor of an anger that could level forests, “You want to talk about hypocrisy, Child?!” He slams his fist on the polished desk, causing its content to rattle anxiously, “you spent your last three years licking fifteen pairs of boots until you could see your goddamn reflection in them! The President finishes his tirade, leaving his face reddened and you utterly speechless. Be All My Sins Remembered

" e.pages = ["

The soft whir of recording equipment is barely audible beneath the voice of prosecutor Robert H. Jackson as he displayed the evidence to the jury. All around the United States of America, people are sitting by their radios, beholding the trial of the man who tried to kill democracy, taking down a beloved veteran in the process. Your hands shake behind the wood of the witness box, thankfully obscured from the scrutiny of your peers, but nothing can conceal the gauntness of your cheeks or the grey strands in your hair. Three more weeks in your cell would be preferable to a second more of this humiliation.

Only MacNider had managed to escape the wrath of the new President, slipping through the FBI’s fingers and disappearing into Canada, whilst the rest of your former allies were thrown in jail on charges of treason. A conviction was guaranteed, so the plan became one of silence, a last attempt to retain your collective dignity in the face of oblivion. Then Clark squealed, and the first domino fell. One by one, the other putschists began to point fingers, shifting blame for the more unsavoury acts of your administration in an effort to avoid the rope, and, as expected, the accusations always led back to you.

Now, here you were, neck deep in your own sins, the once coveted title of President nothing more than a target on your back. How you wished you had let Davis take the position all those years ago.

“Mister Child. Mister Child!” The prosecutor's voice pierces through your haze, unceremoniously pulling you from the swamp of self pity. Your gaze slowly swivels to meet his, acknowledging him for the first time since you took the stand. His bespectacled face shows no remorse or restraint, just a silent, calculated fury that had felled your comrades and would fell you too.

“I had asked you a question, Mister Child,” he continues, readjusting his glasses, “what role did you play in the kidnapping of the Butler family?”

You turn your head towards your lawyer, trying to analyse his facial expressions for a hint of advice. Silence - that was the plan. But the plan was dead. At this point, silence would be cowardice. Had you really come this far, ruined this many lives, just to hide behind a veil of false ignorance?

“Mister Child,” the judge interjects, “answer the question.”

You take a deep breath.

“I suggested the idea and helped plan the operation. I did not participate myself.”

The courtroom fills with murmurs, only to be muzzled by the swift slam of the judge’s gavel. Jackson’s eyes briefly flit to his notes before once again cornering you beneath his glare. “Why did you suggest this in the first place?”

“General Butler was resistant to our ideas. We were worried he would tell the government about the march. It was a necessity to secure his loyalty for as long as we needed him.”

Jackson’s mouth twists into a thin line, disgust barely concealed in his tone. “Do you regret initiating this plan?”

You look past the prosecutor and see him at the back of the hall; President Van Zandt, his fists clenched on his lap. Beside him, Ethel Conway Peters, still pale from her years in isolation, wipes tears from her eyes. The chair next to them is empty. Butler’s.

Handing Off The Strings

" e.pages = ["

No matter how hard you searched, nowhere in the Capitol was quiet. Everywhere you went, you could still hear them, cheering and whooping like fools. Thousands of happy, eager people, all here to celebrate someone else. Like the last four years had never happened. Like you had never been there. And that song - that wretched song. It wormed its way through every crack in the building just to taunt you. Even now, as you leaned against the wall of some empty hallway in a far off wing most congressmen never ventured to, that familiar piano tinkled faintly in the back of your mind.

“Every man a king! Every man a king!”

Every man but you, apparently.

The Committee held some responsibility, of course; if their political apparatus was truly as sophisticated as they claimed, then no primary challenger would’ve come anywhere near to a victory, let alone one built on shrewd politicking. Yet, at a fundamental level, you knew this loss was your fault. That’s what made it hurt so much. You had bought into your own lies, allowed yourself to become complacent enough that an entire scheme to dethrone you successfully played out beneath your nose, and now, for your hubris, you were to be resigned to the dustbin of history. Forgotten in place of a loudmouth from Louisiana. Somewhere in the back of your mind, a small but insistent part of you said that you deserved it.

The sound of polished shoes on waxed wood echo down the hall, approaching your sanctuary of silence. Turning your eyes up from the floor, your nose wrinkles in distaste as you identify the intruder.

“There you are,” Long chuckles, the smile on his face irritatingly sincere. “I was starting to worry you had disappeared. Can’t have the previous President running off on Inauguration Day, can we?” He joins you at the wall, mimicking your posture as he stuffs his hands in his pockets and looks you up and down with something close to concern, “How are you feeling?”

The question catches you off guard. He should be here to laugh at you, but instead he’s offering, what, consolation? No, pity. It must be. You scoff. “Like a fool.”

”Well, I can't blame you,” the Governor concedes, his usually booming voice reduced to a sympathetic murmur. “A bunch of rich snobs bled you dry, and for what? A loss. And they don’t even have the dignity to look you in the eye afterwards-”

You cut him off with a sneer, “are you just here to rub it in, Huey?”

He shakes his head, “far from it, my friend. I'm here to offer you a chance.”

A snort escapes your nose, “a chance to what? Redeem myself?”

Long laughs - a deep, jovial guffaw. “Do I look like a priest to you? No, not a chance at redemption. A chance to get even,” he takes a moment to gauge your reaction, and, sensing hesitation, continues; “There's no need to lie to me, Dick, everyone in the party knows it. All those fellas up in the stands, sitting on piles of cash they leeched off the common man? The ones who pulled your strings and sullied your honor like it was nothing? You hate them, Richard. And I hate them, too.”

“The Committee was right,” you retort, your voice wavering. “You are a socialist.”

“I'm no more of a socialist than your pal in Rome,” he fires back, “He doesn't have a cabal of shady elites controlling him, does he?”

Huffing reluctantly, you manage a shrug, “I suppose not. Doesn't matter now, though. My time in office is over. I've made my mistakes and I've just got to live with them.”

“Do you, now? What a dour point of view.” The President-to-be inches closer, “you were always one of the good ones, Richard. One of the few people in power who actually tried to help Americans, regardless of their status. You could still make a difference in, say, the Department of Commerce.”

The silence stretches between you. The Department of Commerce? He wasn’t… He couldn’t be… You school your features, maintaining an air of indifference. “As an employee?”

“As the head.”

“The head…?” You look down at your hands, clenching and unclenching them like you were unsure if this was reality. Such an offer made no sense. “What, so I'd just be becoming your puppet instead?”

“Oh, no, not at all! You'd have full control, just like any good department head does,” Long clarifies, stepping backwards to allow you room to think. “My brother, Earl, will be taking the Treasury, and he's a big fan of your ideas. Just imagine the look on Ford or Hearst's face when you two smash their monopolies: what a sight!”

The words take a moment to process. A position in Long’s cabinet? The loss of the primaries had been so crushing that you had all but accepted your loss of power to be inevitable, and, yet, here was the man who had ruthlessly outfoxed you, offering not only a hand up, but an opportunity to take revenge on those who wronged you. He had an ulterior motive, you were sure of that, but… did it matter? You knew the Committee’s aims and you still sold yourself to them - at least Long was offering a level of autonomy they never gave you.

Clearly concerned by the length of your deliberation, the governor speaks up once more, “Prescott and Hugh will be returning to their positions, too. I'm sure they'd be delighted to work alongside you again-”

“Don’t.” The word falls out of your mouth. Desperate. Eager. You raise your eyes to meet his. “I mean, you don’t need to convince me any further. I’ll do it. I'll take the position”

Any residual tension dissipates as Long’s face lights up like a Child handed a present. “Now, that's the Richard I know!” he exulted, clapping a hand firmly on your back so hard you wobble slightly. “We'll show those bastards they messed with the wrong President! Come on, straighten up that tie - I want you on stage when I give my speech.”

You manage a simper back, “Of course, Hue- Mister President.”"] e.image = "https://i.postimg.cc/K84WHDjS/MOW-Ending-17-Image.png"; if (SongChange != 1) { const longEnding = new Playlist(); ctsAchievement("Always a bigger Kingfish"); const longSong = new Song( "Every Man A King-Goodbye Huey Long", "Louisiana Ramblers", "https://i.postimg.cc/4x3jHbwT/MOW-Every-Man-A-King.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/9q8KWCULKbwnQHjSLpfupkjxaatSOUnJ" ); longEnding.addSong(longSong); SongChange = 1; changePlaylist(longEnding); } return construct(0); } //Civil War Endings if (IWWAgitation > 16 && LegionLeader === 1) { //Special Formatting document.head.innerHTML += ` ` corrr = '\n

THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL

“As long as we have Hawaii, the Communists can never win.” - Richard Washburn Child\n '; nct_stuff.themes[nct_stuff.selectedTheme].coloring_title = "#ffffff"; nct_stuff.themes[nct_stuff.selectedTheme].coloring_window = "#c7c7c7"; document.getElementsByClassName("game_header")[0].style.backgroundColor = nct_stuff.themes[nct_stuff.selectedTheme].coloring_title; $("#game_window")[0].style.backgroundColor = "#ffffff"; $(".container")[0].style.backgroundColor = "#ffffff"; document.getElementById("header").src = "https://i.postimg.cc/Bvfs2kQS/MOW-Ending-14-Banner.png"; document.body.background = "https://i.postimg.cc/J7pkKcXV/MOW-Ending-14-Background.png"; //Ending content e.header = "

Hawaii (United States of America)

" e.pages = ["

Hawaii, officially the United States of America (USA), is a country in the Pacific Ocean about 2,000 miles (3,200 km) southwest of the American Commonwealth. It has a total area of 28,311 square kilometres (10,931 square miles), with 58.8% of it being composed of land, and the remaining 41.2% water. The combined territories under USA control consist of 137 volcanic islands that comprise the entire Hawaiian archipelago. The largest metropolitan area is that of New Washington (the capital), formerly Honolulu, which is located on the island of Washburn, formerly Oʻahu. With around 3.5 million inhabitants, Hawaii is the most densely populated country in North America.

Settled by Polynesians sometime between 1000 and 1200 CE, Hawaii was home to numerous independent chiefdoms. In 1778, British explorer James Cook was the first known non-Polynesian to arrive at the archipelago. An influx of European and American explorers, traders, and whalers soon arrived, leading to the decimation of the once-isolated indigenous community through the introduction of diseases such as syphilis, tuberculosis, smallpox, and measles; the native Hawaiian population declined from between 300,000 and one million to less than 40,000 by 1890. Hawaii became a unified, internationally recognized kingdom in 1810, remaining independent until American and European businessmen overthrew the monarchy in 1893; this led to annexation by the U.S. in 1898. The Second American Revolution (1936-1945) resulted in the loss of the American mainland to Socialist forces and the flight of the USA central government to Hawaii. The victorious Socialists proceeded to establish the American Commonwealth under Provisional Chairwoman Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, and took the USA’s position as the dominant geopolitical power in North America.

Though fleeing to the island as a nominally fascist one-party state, the death of President Richard Washburn Child in 1946 saw the USA slowly transition back into a liberal democracy over the course of three decades, with democratically elected presidents being reinstated in 1976. Historians largely attribute this slow change in policy to a mix of numerous factors, including the capitulation of the Kingdom of Italy in 1945, diplomatic pressure from the British Empire, and the governmental purges by President Douglas MacArthur (1946-1964). The first democratically elected President of the USA post-second revolution was Nelson Rockefeller, standing for the American Liberty League.

The political status of the USA is contentious. The USA maintains its claim of being the sole legitimate government of America, and it regards the American Commonwealth as an illegal entity. In turn, the American Commonwealth also denies the legitimacy of the USA, claiming it occupies territory that belongs to an indigenous republic. Though formerly recognised by both the British and Japanese empires, the normalization of relations between the American Commonwealth and Britain in the 70s led to them recognising the Commonwealth instead, whilst the collapse of the Japanese Empire in 1991 deprived the USA of their final major international backer. Very few nations currently recognise the USA as a country, with the most notable being the State of Mexico."] e.image = "https://i.postimg.cc/8CdG44jh/MOW-Ending-14-Image.png"; if (SongChange != 1) { const flynnEnding = new Playlist(); ctsAchievement("Taiwan-ification"); const flynnSong = new Song( "Hold the Fort", "Pete Seeger, The Almanac Singers", "https://i.postimg.cc/WpYYhMLr/MOW-Almanac-Singers.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/5Ak7TOMLD2OakpDbm3IuK01MLaWhRSTF" ); flynnEnding.addSong(flynnSong); SongChange = 1; changePlaylist(flynnEnding); } return construct(0); } if (IWWAgitation > 16 && LegionLeader === 2) { //Special Formatting corrr = '\n

JAPANESE DESTROYER SUNK BY US MILITARY

" e.pages = ["

SUNDAY, JANUARY 26TH, 1947

On Wednesday the 22nd, at 20:08 HST, the Japanese Akizuki-class destroyer Niizuki was sunk eight miles off the coast of Kauai after being struck by a barrage of rounds shot from Hawaiian coastal artillery. The ship, which, according to Japanese officials, had been patrolling the area to protect Japanese merchant vessels following numerous skirmishes between the two countries over their pacific claims, entered the US’s territorial waters without their express permission, resulting in a brief shootout. Of the exactly 300 crewmembers aboard, roughly half perished, with the United States Military claiming to have taken 143 Japanese personnel prisoner.

The Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs has denounced the sinking as “an act of US aggression” and have demanded the immediate release of the detained sailors, alongside the payment of 500,000USD in reparations. The US Military, for their part, have justified their actions as self-defence, accusing the Japanese of purposefully provoking their forces by entering Hawaiian waters and citing international precedent for the incarceration of the crewmembers. As of Friday the 24th, Secretary of State George Marshall has formally announced that the nation would not be submitting to any of the Japanese demands.

This incident comes after years of increasing tensions between the Japanese Empire and the rump United States of America (since reduced to just Hawaii and a number of other pacific island possessions following the end of the Second American Civil War in 1942). Former Prime Minister Yonai’s failed attempts to muscle the USA into the Co-Prosperity Sphere back in 1945 is seen by many as the beginning of this diplomatic schism, with the irredentism and anti-Japanese sentiment of General-President Patton only exacerbating the situation.

International observers have voiced concerns that this dispute may soon spiral into open conflict, which threatens to upset a region still reeling from the fallout of the Second World War. HAPPY LIBERATION DAY: 10 YEARS OF ANARCHY!

" e.pages = ["

SUNDAY, SEPTMEBER 4TH, 1949

Most people remember where they were when they heard that George Moseley was captured. My wife was with her militia, garrisoning a newly-occupied Columbus. My brother was back up in Chicago, helping sort rations in our neighbourhood’s distribution center. As for me, I was down in Louisiana, watching in person as my comrades apprehended the tyrant.

It was a sunny day in New Orleans, the clear sky giving an incongruous tone to the fierce battle waging below. The Red Guard detachment I was commanding had just managed to dislodge the last few Legionnaires holding out in the city’s port, disarming the meagre number who surrendered and reappropriating their defenses in case of a counter-attack. Overall, the assault on the fascists’ temporary capital had been going better for us than expected. The other captains and I had gloomily expected it to turn into one long, drawn-out siege, but, much to our (at the time unknown) luck, part of the Generalissimo’s inner circle had rebelled against him, depriving his remaining troops of half a command structure. It seemed that, from the moment it had overthrown its predecessor, to its very last fight, Moseley’s regime was destined to cannibalise itself.

Exhausted from lugging around sandbags, I slumped down against the wall of a nearby warehouse, pulling out my pocket-sized edition of Malatesta’s At The Café for entertainment. Yet, I had made it through no more than three sentences before the crack of rifle fire sent me running towards the embankment. The militiamen perched at the edge of the harbor had spotted a small boat sailing southwards down the Mississippi, a small group of shoddily cloaked figures aboard. The lack of a red or white flag had immediately heightened my comrades’ suspicions, and, when the vessel had refused their orders to stop, they opened fire with the intention to sink. Bullets swiftly peppered the hull, sending the craft beneath the waves and its passengers scrambling towards the shore. Unfortunately for them, the only path back to dry land was via our position.

One by one, the failed escapees were pulled ashore, their sodden disguises torn off to reveal none other than the American Mussolini and his personal guard. At first, my compatriots and I were in disbelief - there was a higher chance we had captured an unfortunate lookalike than the man himself - but the medals, the entourage, they were confirmation enough. I scrambled over the rubble to find our radio officer, shaking her by the shoulders as I ordered her to relay the news. The machine whirred to life, four words transmitting throughout the city: “We have the President.”

Slowly, the bursts of gunfire and artillery that had permeated the day’s events went quiet, bathing New Orleans in a ghostly silence. Then, a cheer. From the streets, the harbors and the field hospitals, people cried out in joy and relief. Three years of hell were finally over. Tears trickled down the faces of even my most aloof comrades as they held each other and discussed what they would do when they returned home to their loved ones. It wasn’t until I touched my face I realised I was weeping too. The Generalissimo spat at my feet, declaring me an “limp-wristed prissy”, but I couldn’t bring myself to care. He wasn’t in charge anymore, and he never would be again.

Even now, when I think of that day, my eyes mist up. The celebrations in Chicago, my meeting with Chairman Tresca, they were all great celebrations that hold a dear place in my heart, but none hold a candle to the sheer emotion that overcame the battlefield that day. The knowledge that the sacrifices we made had ended such a horrendous chapter of American history, that those we had lost had not died in vain, lifted an emotional burden brought on by eighteen months of war, even just for a couple minutes. Whenever that burden weighs on me again, as it often does, all it takes is one look outside at a world freer and fairer than ever before, and I am blessed with that feeling once more.

Happy Liberation Day, comrades. Here's to many more."] e.image = "https://i.postimg.cc/L8596W3y/MOW-Ending-16-Image.png"; if (SongChange != 1) { const trescaEnding = new Playlist(); ctsAchievement("Thus Unto Tyrants"); const trescaSong = new Song( "Bella Ciao", "Manu Pilas", "https://i.postimg.cc/4NCMyK34/MOW-Bella-Ciao.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/JFXMZvNUP4PgWfx4L8o90kkGsW0804DP" ); trescaEnding.addSong(trescaSong); SongChange = 1; changePlaylist(trescaEnding); } return construct(0); } } if (aa[0].electoral_votes < 266) { //Draw Endings if (PartyComposition === 1) { e.header = "

WHITE HOUSE DISCORD - IS HOOVER’S TRIP VOLUNTARY?

" e.pages = ["

When last year’s contingent election resulted in a ground-breaking agreement between the American Liberty League and Republican Party to share the executive branch, with former Vice President Murphy even resigning to allow for the ascension of Herbert Hoover, few believed that the resulting administration would be as optimistic as advertised. Sure enough, after an extended, yet tentative honeymoon period, Vice President Herbert Hoover has announced that he will be going on a two month diplomatic trip to Europe, visiting countries such as the United Kingdom and Italy in an attempt to ease tensions on the currently volatile continent. Needless to say, such a notoriously isolationist man embarking on a highly interventionist quest has raised eyebrows amongst the American public, not least Hoover’s own supporters - some of whom believe the trip isn’t his choice.

Gossip of underhanded deals and shady maneuverings have been a staple of President Child’s time in office long before he was forced to work with Hoover, yet, with new aides in the White House, many of whom have no loyalty to the ALL, these stories have become much more frequent. A common rumor floating around the beltway is that the two recently had a very intense argument about the direction of American foreign policy, resulting in Child refusing to talk to Hoover anymore, only communicating via memo. Another tells of Hoover’s attempts to sabotage a bill providing federal relief to small business owners by forcing the resignation of Hugh Johnson, former Secretary of Labor and a close ally of Child’s. Whilst the truth of either of these tales can hardly be verified, many view them as indicative of the deteriorating relationship between the two politicians.

Those who do believe these leaks, however, speculate that either of these conflicts could be the reason behind the Vice President’s uncharacteristic departure. Hoover’s own former running mate, Robert Taft, has openly accused President Child of “effectively exiling” his VP from Washington D.C. to prevent him from intervening in the ALL’s agenda. In response, a spokesperson for the ALL denounced Taft’s allegations as “nonsense”, in turn accusing him of being “bitter” over his denial of the Vice Presidency. Regardless of the intention behind Hoover’s trip, the reality is mostly in line with Taft’s worries, as the Vice President’s absence from the halls of power nullifies his ability to influence or block any actions he’s opposed to. RECOVERED TRANSCRIPT OF THE MEETING BETWEEN CORDELL HULL AND JOSEPH IRWIN FRANCE, DATED 11/8/1936

" e.pages = ["

(The tape begins. There is a faint squeak of leather as one of the politicians takes a seat, followed by a long, pensive silence. Eventually, the leather chair is heard again, as someone, presumably the same politician from earlier, stands up and walks away from the recording device. A cabinet door creaks open and a glass container is retrieved from it before it is slammed shut. The man walks back over towards the table with the recording device and pours two glasses of liquid. One is audibly filled more than the other. The glass container is then placed on the table and the politician sits back down. A couple more seconds of silence pass.)

FRANCE: So… Not him?

HULL: Not him.

FRANCE: Definitely not him.

HULL: Anyone but him.

FRANCE: One of us two, you mean.

HULL: What, do you think I’m going to suggest Norman fucking Thomas?

FRANCE: No, no, of course not… I’m just nervous. This hasn’t happened in a hundred years, there’s no telling how this will go. Who Child and his allies have in their pocket.

HULL: Calm down, Joseph, agonizing won’t help either of us. Take a drink and breathe.

(France does as suggested, taking a sip from his glass and sighing.)

FRANCE: Okay… Let’s work this out. Which one of us will become the president?

HULL: I trust you can take that position.

FRANCE: And the VP slot?

HULL: Me, naturally.

FRANCE: But that would completely sideline our running mates.

HULL: It’s the Vice Presidency. They’re not missing out on much.

FRANCE: I suppose it works well enough as a compromise. Still, I worry we won’t have enough votes to secure both spots.

HULL: Our parties put together hold a majority of delegates in both houses. That’s all we need.

FRANCE: But how do we guarantee that they vote for us? There’s decades of anonymity between us which the ALL simply doesn’t have. Whole blocs of your party could end up voting for Child just to make sure I don’t become President, and vice versa.

HULL: I don’t doubt there’ll be stragglers, especially with our men in the deep south, but there’s already precedent for cooperation between us. If we could convince our respective conventions to endorse each other-

FRANCE: You’re not seriously suggesting a National Unity ticket?

HULL: Sixty two congressional districts had National Unity tickets two years ago. That amount has almost doubled this election. There is a clear desire amongst our voters for our parties to cooperate against the ALL.

FRANCE: I don’t know if that’s precedent enough…

HULL: Lincoln did it. Why can’t we?

FRANCE: You are aware that Lincoln got shot, Cordell?

HULL: Well, unless the assassin gets us whilst we’re standing in a line, we should be alright.

(There is another long pause.)

FRANCE: I think I actually want to be Vice President."] //e.image = "" e.image = "https://i.postimg.cc/7PWhvns2/MOW-Ending-6-Image.png"; if (SongChange != 1) { const nationalUnionEnding = new Playlist(); ctsAchievement("Anyone but Him"); const nationalUnionSong = new Song( "Union Dixie", "Tennessee Ernie Ford", "https://i.postimg.cc/nc7yG4WQ/MOW-Union-Dixie.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/pDSey4vhJiMRMVi6lE2LXF4YdkbTSwxn" ); nationalUnionEnding.addSong(nationalUnionSong); SongChange = 1; changePlaylist(nationalUnionEnding); } return construct(0); } if (PartyComposition === 3) { e.header = "

THE ELECTION SAFEGUARDING ACT: CHILD SAVES DEMOCRACY!

" e.pages = ["

The election of the crypto-socialist PFLA ticket back in 1932 was a shock to all good Americans. How could a party so fundamentally opposed to the core values of our great nation manage to worm its way into power? The answer is simple: voter fraud. Thousands upon thousands of false ballots casted by judeo-narodnik infiltrators resulted in the victory of that addled old man, Coxey, and his serpent Vice President, placing our country on the precipice of a far-left coup. If it wasn’t for the bravery of the Legion and the genius of great men such as Butler and Child, American democracy would be dead, squished under the heel of the Soviets.

Whilst, thankfully, the presidency is no longer occupied by these saboteurs, that doesn’t mean we are free from socialist subversion. The inconclusive result of the 1936 election is glaring proof that these cockroaches still infest our political system, undermining it at every turn. Well, if Spiridonova thought that burdening our President with a Democratic VP would stop his crusade against her vile ideology, she was wrong. Child and Garner have proven to be a solid pair, and their selfless devotion to upholding traditional American principles has (as of yesterday’s Senate vote) culminated in the implementation of the Election Safeguarding Act.

A product of close collaboration between the American Liberty League and a number of southern Democratic governors, this bill is a massive step forward in eradicating voter fraud and counteracting the influence of this “fifth column”. From now on, citizens will be required to show a form of government identification with them if they wish to vote, as to prevent known agitators from interfering in the democratic process. This new provision, combined with the introduction of national guardsmen at polling stations and a nationwide ban on pro-socialist propaganda, has done much to relieve the public’s fear of future elections being tampered with.

Of course, no attempt to make this country safer can happen without fierce opposition from Soviet sympathisers in the Republican and Democratic parties. Despite the best efforts by Garner and the respectable faction of his party, liberal Democrats have been crossing the aisle to collaborate with Republicans on illegal schemes to shut down the act before it can fully come into effect. Known proto-progressive Earl Warren has even submitted an appeal to the Supreme Court, baselessly claiming that many of the bill’s provisions are unconstitutional. Whilst it’s too early to know how this ridiculous case will conclude, we here at The Patriot have full faith in the court to make the right decision and dismiss Warren’s arguments.
